topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Cold open on why storytelling/public speaking matters for promotion, then Lenny introduces Petra Wille, her coaching work, and the episode’s three focus areas.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Flatfile (CSV import/onboarding), Mixpanel (self-serve product analytics), and later AssemblyAI (audio/video AI models).

topics.title: Petra’s coaching work and impact
topics.summary: Petra explains who she coaches (product leaders and previously IC PMs), how her work spans 1:1, group, and org coaching, and estimates her broader ripple-effect impact.

topics.title: Why middle-layer product leaders matter
topics.summary: They discuss why first-line managers/directors are highly influential, and Petra notes many product leaders come from non-product backgrounds and lack empathy for PM challenges.

topics.title: Common gaps for non-product product leaders
topics.summary: Petra highlights two big misses: leaders don’t curate PM learning using the broader product community, and they underestimate the role’s multi-skill complexity (beyond “T-shaped”).

topics.title: Petra’s book: Strong Product People
topics.summary: Petra describes her niche book for people managing PMs, focused on coaching and developing PM capabilities (feedback, discovery, motivation) rather than only strategy creation.

topics.title: Five ingredients to coach PMs well
topics.summary: Petra lays out her coaching framework: define what “good” looks like, assess current state, set a shared vision and next challenge, create a development plan, and follow up consistently.

topics.title: Where to start: development plans and follow-up
topics.summary: They discuss the most practical starting point—helping PMs build a development plan and nudging progress—plus Lenny’s example of monthly check-ins tied to review goals.

topics.title: Defining competent PMs: ladders, traits, assessments
topics.summary: Petra recommends borrowing and customizing existing PM competency assessments, and emphasizes hiring for harder-to-train traits like curiosity and empathy.

topics.title: PMwheel framework overview
topics.summary: Petra explains her PMwheel’s eight buckets (problem/solution, planning, delivery, learn/iterate, team, personal growth, agile) and how to use self/manager/team assessments.

topics.title: Practical coaching: questions and 1:1 structure
topics.summary: Petra suggests keeping a ready list of coaching questions (including emotion prompts) and references Mochary-style scaling questions to improve 1:1 quality and trust.

topics.title: Storytelling basics: time investment and human language
topics.summary: Petra argues storytelling takes significant prep time (e.g., weeks for a quarterly narrative) and advises removing jargon in favor of vivid, human language that connects emotionally.

topics.title: Public speaking: practice, feedback, and nerves
topics.summary: They cover how to improve public speaking by starting with small friendly audiences, seeking feedback, and using pre-talk techniques (power poses, tapping) to manage anxiety.

topics.title: Career impact of storytelling and role models
topics.summary: Petra explains why weak storytelling/public speaking can stall promotions (though teams can sometimes compensate) and begins citing a standout storyteller leader (Jason Goldberg).
